awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikurangi convergent margin
awd_abstract_narration:
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikurangi convergent margin

The physical processes dictating the spectrum of fault slip modes (spanning destructive earthquakes to slow slip events and aseismic creep) and the links between these behaviors and long-term morphotectonic evolution of subduction systems are not understood. There is a fundamental need to address this important problem with an integrated, system-level approach combining geodynamical modeling with high-quality geophysical and geological constraints on subduction margin characteristics.

This project will conduct an interdisciplinary, multinational collaborative program involving the USA, New Zealand, Japan and the UK to evaluate system-level controls on processes that govern both slip behavior and long-term deformation at subduction zones. The focus is on the Hikurangi margin in New Zealand, where GPS data show a transition in slip behavior from predominantly stick-slip in the south to aseismic creep in the northern North Island, and where a wide range of subduction-related processes and characteristics vary along-strike. The aim is to rigorously investigate the feedbacks between plate interface slip behavior, solid and fluid mass fluxes, and manifestations of plate boundary mechanics in the long-term geological record that likely reflect common driving processes linking forearc uplift, sediment transfer and underplating, plate boundary strength, and seismogenesis. The Principal Investigators will address this important problem through an integrated approach combining large-scale seismic imaging, paleoseismology, and geomorphology, focused through the lens of state-of-the-art numerical modelling.

Sizing up the Taniwha: Seismogenesis at Hikurangi Integrated Research Experiment (SHIRE) - Geomorphic & Paleoseismic Studies

"It does not do to leave a live dragon out of your calculations, if you live near him." Gandalf the Wizard (The Hobbit by J.R.R. Tolkien)

 

 A Live Dragon Beneath the Sea

In New Zealand's Māori culture, the Taniwha is a dragon-like beast that lives beneath the water, sometimes protecting seafarers, while at other times wreaking disaster on coastal communities. Māori lore tells of Taniwha that cause sudden upheavals and changes in the coastline, altering the shape of the land-ocean interface. In the wake of New Zealand's 2016 Magnitude 7.8 Kaikoura Earthquake, the Taniwha was evoked as a supernatural force behind coastal uplift, tsunami, and landslides. For New Zealand, the Hikurangi subduction margin is a formidable Taniwha, a "live dragon" lurking just offshore, ready to unleash powerful forces locked within its seismogenic zone. With multiple collaborative research efforts now underway, geoscientists are shedding light on the habits of this secretive dragon, revealing new understandings of the earthquake and tsunami hazards that threaten New Zealand's coastline.

 

The SHIRE Project

The Hikurangi subduction margin along the east coast of New Zealand's North Island provides an optimal venue for investigating megathrust fault behavior and controls on earthquake genesis. The characteristics of subduction vary systematically along the length of the margin, providing unique opportunities to investigate physical controls on tectonic deformation and earthquake behavior. Much of the deformation zone is exposed on land and therefore ideal for geodetic and geologic studies, while the undersea areas are easily accessible for geophysical imaging and monitoring. The SHIRE Project, funded by the NSF Integrated Earth Systems (IES) Program, was a five-year, multi-disciplinary, land and sea research effort involving a team of investigators at five US institutions, as well as international collaborators from New Zealand, Japan, and the United Kingdom. This project was designed to evaluate controls on megathrust fault behavior by combining both on and offshore seismic imaging, with onshore paleoseismic, geomorphic, and geodetic investigations. The overarching goal was to develop an integrated perspective of the physical mechanisms controlling subduction zone fault behavior and convergent margin tectonic evolution. Importantly, this perspective helps to elucidate a clearer picture of megathrust earthquake and tsunami hazards along New Zealand's Hikurangi margin.

 

Geomorphic & Paleoseismic Studies

The SHIRE Project's coastal uplift and paleoseismic studies (focus of this report) were conducted by Dr. Jeff Marshall and students from Cal Poly Pomona University. This research investigated tectonic deformation in the coastal region, focusing on geomorphic records of land level changes related to the subduction earthquake cycle. These studies targeted sites along the North Island east coast that compliment ongoing investigations by New Zealand's GNS Science. Fieldwork, lab work, and data analysis from this project resulted in significant advancements in our understanding of tectonic deformation and earthquake hazards along the Hikurangi Margin. This research examined the morphotectonics and paleoseismology of coastal terraces and ancient shorelines across two time scales: 1) cumulative deformation patterns exhibited by late Pleistocene coastal terraces (100,000 to 10,000 years), and 2) episodic earthquake uplift events preserved by Holocene paleo-shorelines (10,000 years to present). Fieldwork was conducted during three expeditions in 2017, 2018, and 2019, targeting six principle field areas (from south to north): A) Southern Wairarapa Coast (Te Kaukau Point to Flat Point), B) Central Wairarapa Coast (Flat Point to Whareama River), C) Northern Wairarapa Coast (Porangahau to Pourerere), D) Southern Hawkes Bay (Waimarama to Clifton), E) Northern Hawkes Bay (Mahia Peninsula), and F) Gable End Coast (Gisborne to Pakarae River).

To identify prehistoric earthquakes and evaluate net coastal uplift patterns, Marshall and students mapped, surveyed, and sampled uplifted paleo-shorelines and coastal terraces at multiple sites. Drone videos were recorded to aid in shoreline mapping. Marine shells were collected for radiocarbon dating from elevated tidal platforms and overlying beach sediments. Recently acquired airborne LiDAR imagery (provided by GNS Science) was used to correlate ancient shorelines between field sites and track lateral variations in coastal uplift. Marshall and students also mapped and sampled flights of uplifted Pleistocene marine terraces to evaluate longer-term coastal uplift rates and deformation patterns. Terrace cover beds were sampled for infrared stimulated luminescence (IRSL) age dating, and for the identification of volcanic tephra deposits of known ages. Terrace deformation patterns were studied using LiDAR digital terrain analysis.

As primary outcomes of this project, the Cal Poly Pomona SHIRE Research Team expanded on earlier North Island geomorphic and paleoseismic studies, modernized paleo-shoreline mapping using LiDAR imagery, filled significant data gaps in the coastal uplift record, and updated constraints on ancient earthquake events with new age dating and recalibration of prior ages. Importantly, these advances contribute toward a more robust knowledge of tectonic deformation and earthquake hazards along the Hikurangi Margin.
